results.title: Graham Sutherland
results.creator_credit: John Read, John Elliot and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: A films about distinguished English painter best known for his portraits of Somerset Maugham, Lord Beaverbrook and Sir Winston Churchill. Sutherland is, however, a landscape artist who treats his subjects in a highly personal and poetic manner, which goes beyond surface realism. Descriptive sequences were specially shot in Pembrokeshire and in the South of France to show landscapes which have influenced his painting. The film concludes with a personal statement by the artist about his approach to his work.

results.title: Graduate harvest
results.brief_description: Massey College, situated in Palmerston North, is an agricultural college attached to the university of New Zealand. Students, including many from other parts of the world, attend coursers in horticulture, fruit growing, cheese and butter making, dairying and the raising of sheep and pigs.

results.title: Goya: the disasters of war (TEFC)
results.brief_description: In 1807, Spain was “peacefully” invaded by the armies of Napoleon, plunging the country into a long, cruel and bloody war. Francisco de Goya, the great Spanish painter, recorded the catastrophe of this war in a series of lithographs which are reproduced in this film. The transition from peace to rebellion, the brutality and futility of total war, and the grimness of death, are portrayed with bitter clarity by the artist. Narrated by Joseph Armesto and American narration by Frank Gehlein.

results.title: Government
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Describes through the eyes of a middle-management Social Security employee, the role America’s government - the largest single employer, spender, borrower, and consumer in the country - has played in determining America’s economic growth. It tells why, and where the government has been involved in communications, agriculture, forestry, mining, transportation, banking and commerce, workers’ rights, health and welfare, and protection of the environment. Presented by William Shatner.

results.title: Gould League snake show. Gould League reptile show
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Lily Steiner and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: (Compilation Tape) The first program (15min) has children simulating a snake. It investigates a snake’s features and looks at people’s attitudes towards them through the eyes of someone from another planet. The second program (14min) uses art activities and simple experiments to demonstrate how reptiles live. Examples of living reptiles are included to highlight their special features.

results.title: Gough Whitlam - Dismissal
results.brief_description: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975.

constellations_primary.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_primary.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

results.description: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General of the day, Sir John Kerr, exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975. Whitlam’s defiance was immortalised in his televised ‘nothing will save the Governor-General’ rebuttal; an impassioned speech in which he implored the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ and which took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy in the face of Labor’s landslide election defeat only a month later, in December 1975.
description_for_label: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General of the day, Sir John Kerr, exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975. Whitlam’s defiance was immortalised in his televised ‘nothing will save the Governor-General’ rebuttal; an impassioned speech in which he implored the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ and which took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy in the face of Labor’s landslide election defeat only a month later, in December 1975.

results.title: Gotterdammerung: fall of the Third Reich
results.creator_credit: Jack Kaufman, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Rise and fall of the Third Reich”.
Third and final part of a series based on the book by William L. Shirer ‘The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich’. This episode deals with the period 1941-1945, showing the first gradual and then accelerated reverses of the German army.

results.title: Gotterdammerung
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Deutsche Grammophon and Metropolitan Opera (New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: This is the final catastrophic opera in Wagner’s ‘The Ring of the Nibelung’. The redemption of the world through love is achieved at the end of Gotterdammerung, with the annihilation of both men and gods. Conducted by James Levine and featuring Siegfried Jerusalem. Wagner’s “Ring Cycle” consists of four parts in the following order: Das Rheingold; Die Walkuere; Siegfreid and Goetterdaemmerung.
